title: View or Edit a Bundle
text: Selecting a Bundle will allow you to view/edit a bundle. NOTE: It is not possible to alter the main item of a bundle. It is recommended that you delete and re create. All the key properties you can edit are explained in the "Create Bundle Wizard" section. The tax rate set here will take preference and apply to the items sold under this Bundle, this may be different to the tax rate set in Inventory. Here you can resequence the order of the Bundle Groups as they will appear to your customers using the Handle in the Bundle Groups row.

title: Creating a New Bundle
text: 1. To begin creating a new bundle click the "Create Bundle" button and the bundle wizard will walk you through the steps. 2. Choose a main item which must already exist in your Items. This item could of course also be linked to Modifier Group. 3. Select the Bundle Groups which you want to offer alongside your Main Item. Click the "Add Bundle Groups" button. 4. You can either Add a Bundle Group or create a new bundle group (for which documentation can be found in the Bundle Groups section). 5. If you select 'Add Bundle Group' it will show you a searchable list of existing Bundle groups You can select multiple bundle groups using the checkboxes on the left-hand side. 6. Once you have selected your bundle groups, you can customise your bundle. On this screen, you add. Name This is the internal name of the Bundle Display Name The bundle name will be displayed on both the details screen of the front-end apps and the receipt. Please ensure that the chosen name accurately reflects the contents of the bundle. Description Allows for longer product descriptions that include dietary and allergen information, helping your customers make informed decisions. Image URL This is a link to the Image that is displayed in the details view of the bundles in the front-end apps. Only .bmp, .gif, .jpg and .svg type images are supported. Sales Price The price the bundle will be sold for. 7. Click next and this shows the summary of the bundle you are creating. 8. You have the option at this point to go to the previous screen and change anything or create the bundle.
description:
1. To begin creating a new bundle click the "Create Bundle" button and the bundle wizard will walk you through the steps.


2. Choose a main item which must already exist in your Items. This item could of course also be linked to Modifier Group.



3. Select the Bundle Groups which you want to offer alongside your Main Item. Click the "Add Bundle Groups" button.



4. You can either Add a Bundle Group or create a new bundle group (for which documentation can be found in the Bundle Groups section).



5. If you select 'Add Bundle Group' it will show you a searchable list of existing Bundle groups You can select multiple bundle groups using the checkboxes on the left-hand side.



6. Once you have selected your bundle groups, you can customise your bundle.

On this screen, you add.


NameThis is the internal name of the Bundle
Display NameThe bundle name will be displayed on both the details screen of the front-end apps and the receipt. Please ensure that the chosen name accurately reflects the contents of the bundle.
DescriptionAllows for longer product descriptions that include dietary and allergen information, helping your customers make informed decisions.
Image URLThis is a link to the Image that is displayed in the details view of the bundles in the front-end apps. Only .bmp, .gif, .jpg and .svg type images are supported.
Sales Price
The price the bundle will be sold for. 




7. Click next and this shows the summary of the bundle you are creating.



8. You have the option at this point to go to the previous screen and change anything or create the bundle.

title: Create a Bundle Group
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Bundle Groups Create a Bundle Group View/Edit Bundle Group Bundle Groups Bundle Groups are a collection of similar items that are presented for selection. For instance, you may have a group of side dishes that can be chosen to go with a main meal. The Bundle Groups selections can only be items and are linked exclusively to Bundles. Items can be added to as many Bundle Groups as needed. Bundle Groups are displayed as selectable items in the front-end applications, similar to the example shown below. The display names of the two Bundle Groups linked to the Bundle are Pastry and Sweet Stuff. The Bundle Group List displays all the groups you have currently set up. From here, you can create a new Bundle Group or select an existing one to view and edit its details. Please note that you cannot delete Bundle Groups that are linked to other Bundles for which sales have already been registered. Create a Bundle Group When creating a new Bundle Group, you will need to specify two key properties and the items you want to include in the group. To start creating a new Bundle Group, click on the "Create Bundle Groups" button. This will open up the following page: Name This should be the name used internaly Display Name This is the name seen by front end users. Add Item to Bundle Group Clicking on this button will display a list of searchable items that can be assigned to the Bundle Group. To add multiple items at once, simply select the checkboxes next to each item and click on the button to assign them. Ensure you press to add the created bundle group to the system. View/Edit Bundle Group To edit a Bundle Group, simply select the group you wish to modify. Note that you can delete items from the group, but this action only removes the item from the group and does not delete the actual item. It's important to keep in mind that any changes made to a Bundle Group will immediately be reflected in any Bundles that are currently live and in use in the front-end applications.

TABLE OF CONTENTS

Bundle Groups

Bundle Groups are a collection of similar items that are presented for selection. For instance, you may have a group of side dishes that can be chosen to go with a main meal. The Bundle Groups selections can only be items and are linked exclusively to Bundles.


Items can be added to as many Bundle Groups as needed.


Bundle Groups are displayed as selectable items in the front-end applications, similar to the example shown below. The display names of the two Bundle Groups linked to the Bundle are Pastry and Sweet Stuff.





The Bundle Group List displays all the groups you have currently set up. From here, you can create a new Bundle Group or select an existing one to view and edit its details.


Please note that you cannot delete Bundle Groups that are linked to other Bundles for which sales have already been registered.


Create a Bundle Group

When creating a new Bundle Group, you will need to specify two key properties and the items you want to include in the group.


To start creating a new Bundle Group, click on the "Create Bundle Groups" button. This will open up the following page:



NameThis should be the name used internaly
Display NameThis is the name seen by front end users.
Add Item to Bundle GroupClicking on this button will display a list of searchable items that can be assigned to the Bundle Group. To add multiple items at once, simply select the checkboxes next to each item and click on the button to assign them.




 Ensure you press to add the created bundle group to the system.


View/Edit Bundle Group

To edit a Bundle Group, simply select the group you wish to modify.


Note that you can delete items from the group, but this action only removes the item from the group and does not delete the actual item.


It's important to keep in mind that any changes made to a Bundle Group will immediately be reflected in any Bundles that are currently live and in use in the front-end applications.

Modifier Groups Modifier Groups enable you to apply certain prescribed modifications to an Item. Note that you can only modify an Item or a Bundle Main item, but not a Bundle Group Item. You would use a Modifier Group if you wish to add one or more variable modifiers to a particular item. Modifiers can have additional prices added on top of the item price. For instance, suppose you order a cup of coffee. You choose a Latte but would also like to select your preferred type of milk, an extra shot of espresso, and a flavour of syrup. This would require three modifier groups: "Milk": This Modifier Group lists the milk options available, such as Semi Skimmed, Skimmed, Whole, Oat, Soy, and Almond. "Shots": This Modifier Group includes the optional extra shots available. "Syrups": This Modifier Group provides the syrup choices. Please note that Modifiers are not currently linked to Items within Imagine and do not affect the stock. Modifiers appear in the front-end apps, similar to the example shown below: Modifier Groups List A Modifier Group List displays all the existing Modifier Groups that you have currently set up. From this list, you can create new Modifier Groups or select an existing one to view or edit its details. Note that you cannot delete Modifier Groups, as they may be linked to other groups for which sales have already been registered. Create a Modifier Group To begin creating modifiers use the This will then open up to the page below. Number Picker Uses a +/- button to increase and decrease selection amounts. Can be used for items like "Extra Shot". Checkbox Buttons Uses tick boxes for selections. Can be used for items like a sandwich with different fillings like lettuce, tomatoes or onion. Name The name is used internally. Display Name The name is seen by front-end users. Number Picker Example. You can add/edit as many different number pickers into your Modifier Group as required within the table. To add more modifiers use the to add a new line. Image Enter a URL for an image to be shown against the modifier in the front-end apps. Only .bmp, .gif, .jpg and .svg type images are supported. Name The name of the modifier as it appears in the front-end apps. ItemNo Used for integration purposes, you can link a modifier to an existing Imagine item which can then be related to a third-party ERP system item. Default Value The number you get by default upon selection. Min The minimum value you can enter for the modifier. Max The maximum number allowed to be entered for the modifier. Sales Price Optional sales prices for modifiers that get added to the price from the default value. As an example, suppose you have set a default value of 1 for shots, and each additional shot costs £1.10. In this case, the price for each shot added will be added to the item price. However, if the default value is 1, but you have set the minimum value to 0, then the price will not be subtracted if the default shot is removed. This means that the customer cannot lower the base price of the item by removing the modifiers. Ensure you save the individual rows before trying to add a new row or save the group. it will only save changes which have been individually saved in that table. Example Coffee Price: £3.00 Shot Price: £1.00 Default Shots: 2 Minimum Shots: 1 Number Of Shots Coffee Total Price Reason 1 £3.00 The base price is £3.00 and they have removed 1 shot, but you do not have the cost of the shot removed for your default shots. 2 £3.00 The default number of shots, therefore default coffee price applies. 3 £4.00 2 default shots are included in the price, and 1 additional shot for £1. 4 £5.00 2 default shots included in the price, s additional shots for £2. Checkbox Button Example. Checkbox Buttons are a type of modifier that allows you to provide one or more selectable options to customers, both as optional or mandatory selections. They are called Checkbox Buttons because they appear as clickable buttons that resemble checkboxes, which can be easily selected with a touch screen. These are particularly useful for providing choices of fillings for sandwiches or toppings for pizzas, for example. Customers can select one or more options or none of them, depending on their preferences. Name This should be the name used internally. Display Name This should be the name seen by front-end users. Min The minimum value you can enter for the modifier. Max The maximum number allowed to be entered for the modifier Checkbox Buttons are a way to offer optional or mandatory selections to customers, where they can choose one or more options from a list. If the modifier is not mandatory, the minimum value should always be 0, while if you want to ensure that at least one modifier is always selected, set the minimum to 1. The maximum value is typically set to 1, to limit the number of selections to one per group. However, for optional toppings, you may choose to set a higher limit. To create or modify modifiers, use the table below. You can add, delete, or modify rows as needed. Remember to save each row before attempting to add a new one or save the group, as changes are only saved for rows that have been individually saved within the table. Image Enter an image URL this will be shown against the modifier at the front end. NOTE: Only .bmp / .gif / .jpg /.svg image types are supported. Name The name of the modifier as it appears in the front-end apps. ItemNo Used for integration purposes, you can link a modifier to an existing Imagine item which can then be related to a third-party ERP system item. Default Value - If the button is selected by default. For example, in a Latte case, you might have Semi Skimmed selected by default. Sales Price Optional sales prices for modifiers that get added to the price of the default value. When you select a syrup for your coffee, an additional charge of £0.50 will be added to the item price. However, if the syrup is set as a default selection, the charge for it will not be subtracted from the item price. You can also set higher prices for more premium modifiers to increase revenue. Keep in mind that any additional charges for modifiers will be added to the item price, so the final price of the item may vary based on the selections made.

Modifier Groups

Modifier Groups enable you to apply certain prescribed modifications to an Item. Note that you can only modify an Item or a Bundle Main item, but not a Bundle Group Item.


You would use a Modifier Group if you wish to add one or more variable modifiers to a particular item. Modifiers can have additional prices added on top of the item price.


For instance, suppose you order a cup of coffee. You choose a Latte but would also like to select your preferred type of milk, an extra shot of espresso, and a flavour of syrup. This would require three modifier groups:


"Milk": This Modifier Group lists the milk options available, such as Semi Skimmed, Skimmed, Whole, Oat, Soy, and Almond.


"Shots": This Modifier Group includes the optional extra shots available.


"Syrups": This Modifier Group provides the syrup choices.


Please note that Modifiers are not currently linked to Items within Imagine and do not affect the stock.


Modifiers appear in the front-end apps, similar to the example shown below:


Modifier Groups List

A Modifier Group List displays all the existing Modifier Groups that you have currently set up. From this list, you can create new Modifier Groups or select an existing one to view or edit its details.


Note that you cannot delete Modifier Groups, as they may be linked to other groups for which sales have already been registered.


Create a Modifier Group

To begin creating modifiers use the This will then open up to the page below.



Number Picker
Uses a +/- button to increase and decrease selection amounts. Can be used for items like "Extra Shot".
Checkbox Buttons
Uses tick boxes for selections. Can be used for items like a sandwich with different fillings like lettuce, tomatoes or onion.
Name
The name is used internally.
Display Name
The name is seen by front-end users.

Number Picker Example.



You can add/edit as many different number pickers into your Modifier Group as required within the table.  To add more modifiers use the to add a new line. 


Image
Enter a URL for an image to be shown against the modifier in the front-end apps. Only .bmp, .gif, .jpg and .svg type images are supported.
Name
The name of the modifier as it appears in the front-end apps.
ItemNo
Used for integration purposes, you can link a modifier to an existing Imagine item which can then be related to a third-party ERP system item.
Default Value
The number you get by default upon selection.
Min
The minimum value you can enter for the modifier.
Max
The maximum number allowed to be entered for the modifier.
Sales Price
Optional sales prices for modifiers that get added to the price from the default value.


As an example, suppose you have set a default value of 1 for shots, and each additional shot costs £1.10. In this case, the price for each shot added will be added to the item price.


However, if the default value is 1, but you have set the minimum value to 0, then the price will not be subtracted if the default shot is removed. This means that the customer cannot lower the base price of the item by removing the modifiers.


Ensure you save the individual rows before trying to add a new row or save the group. it will only save changes which have been individually saved in that table.

Checkbox Button Example.

Checkbox Buttons are a type of modifier that allows you to provide one or more selectable options to customers, both as optional or mandatory selections. They are called Checkbox Buttons because they appear as clickable buttons that resemble checkboxes, which can be easily selected with a touch screen. These are particularly useful for providing choices of fillings for sandwiches or toppings for pizzas, for example. Customers can select one or more options or none of them, depending on their preferences.




Name
This should be the name used internally.
Display Name
This should be the name seen by front-end users.
Min
 The minimum value you can enter for the modifier.
Max
The maximum number allowed to be entered for the modifier


Checkbox Buttons are a way to offer optional or mandatory selections to customers, where they can choose one or more options from a list. If the modifier is not mandatory, the minimum value should always be 0, while if you want to ensure that at least one modifier is always selected, set the minimum to 1. The maximum value is typically set to 1, to limit the number of selections to one per group. However, for optional toppings, you may choose to set a higher limit.


To create or modify modifiers, use the table below. You can add, delete, or modify rows as needed. Remember to save each row before attempting to add a new one or save the group, as changes are only saved for rows that have been individually saved within the table.

NOTE: Only .bmp / .gif / .jpg /.svg  image types are supported.

Default Value
- If the button is selected by default. For example, in a Latte case, you might have Semi Skimmed selected by default.
Sales Price
Optional sales prices for modifiers that get added to the price of the default value.


When you select a syrup for your coffee, an additional charge of £0.50 will be added to the item price. However, if the syrup is set as a default selection, the charge for it will not be subtracted from the item price.


You can also set higher prices for more premium modifiers to increase revenue. Keep in mind that any additional charges for modifiers will be added to the item price, so the final price of the item may vary based on the selections made.
